name: APIs: import, structure, and lifecycle
description: Portal-first workflow for importing APIs and managing changes without breaking consumers.
decision: Will you manage APIs OpenAPI-first (import and update from spec) or portal-first (manual operations), and how will you handle breaking changes?
whyItMatters: API lifecycle choices affect consumer stability and your ability to apply changes safely.
A consistent import/update model reduces drift between spec, APIM configuration, and backend implementation.
Change strategy determines how you communicate and enforce versions and deprecation.
portalSteps: Import an API (OpenAPI where possible) and review operations, request/response shapes, and backend mapping.
Decide a versioning strategy (path, header, or query) and keep it consistent across the API program.
Use revisions to stage non-breaking changes and validate before releasing broadly.
Document which changes require a new API version vs a revision.
validation: Validate imported operations match backend routing and authentication.
Test old and new versions/revisions in parallel if consumers are already integrated.
Confirm policy behavior after import/update (especially at API/operation scope).
pitfalls: Importing a spec but then manually editing operations (drift over time).
No standard for breaking changes (clients get surprised).
Applying policies at multiple scopes without conventions.
nextSteps: Use 11-operations-governance → revisions-versions-rollout for a safer rollout model.
Use 12-policy-guides → policy-placement-guide to standardize where policies live.
